comment: For the price- this is a great great whiskey!  For a fun night and maybe some ice- this is a great choice.
Strong vanilla smell, strong flavor on tongue, smooth down throat.
drank the crap out of this in college and it was fine, now that the wallet is thicker and the palate more seasoned cant really stand it at all.
For lower shelf stuff, I have had better. Very sweet but no balance.

Had a couple glasses of Crown with Dad to celebrate retirement. Bought in 1979 when he started Med school. 7 years aged at the time. Bottled in 1972. Aged in bottle since. Opened and Drank in March 2018. 56 years old. Very smooth. No bite. Quite noticeably smoother than regular crown, and more so than I was expecting.
Have two bottles from 1956, from Arlene.
A really good smooth whiskey. Flavor and scent isn’t as strong as I would prefer, but definitely enough to know this is a solid choice for your dollar.

Nose: It's sweet and smooth straight off the bat. There is vanilla and coconut and the longer I smell it, toasted marshmallow comes to the front.

Taste: Like the Canadians who made her, she's friendly. Vanilla, honey, and graham crackers predominate with some lemongrass making a subtle appearance. The finish is smooth though not very exciting.

Opinion: For those who aren't a fan of drinking whiskey neat, the classic Crown&Coke is a great option here. However, this whisky is so smooth and friendly it can easily be drank neat even by the novice. This is great beginner whisky and also one that experienced drinkers can come to for a smooth not complicated dram. Cheers!
Meh. Won’t buy it, but won’t turn down a drink or two of it either
It's too costly for what it is.  I feel like I can get equivalent quality from Black Velvet for cheaper...

Tried this at an airport lounge before my flight to Vancouver. A good starter whisky which has notes of maple, vanilla, caramel, and spices. Better off mixed. Would like to try the higher end crown royals such as the northern harvest rye, cornerstone, xo, xr, wine cask finish, select barrel, cask 16.
Its crown man, come on. If your mixing some coke and 7up, its with crown. Would i sip it on the rocks? Hell no, but do i love it with diet coke? Hell yea. This canadian whiskey is an American staple.
Full vanilla with a thin-ish texture like sweet liquor. It’s not bad at all.

Nose- Honestly, I can’t smell very much. There is a hint of sweet lemon like a light lemonade. 
Body- There is a little bit of that rye pickle brine here and a lot of sweetness. The 80 proof seems really light in body after what I have been drinking lately.
Finish- Not really much there just bread and butter pickles. Well I don’t like bread and butter pickles. 

One, I have not had any Canadian whiskies that I get excited about. 
Two, this one sure as hell hasn’t changed my mind.

SEHR fruchtige Nase, Geschmack etwas einfach, kein bleibender Eindruck. Leicht zu trinken.

09/18 - Vancouver
I don’t know what is about Crown Royal but it doesn’t agree with my taste buds. Just the smell of it makes me gag. Just me though, my brothers swear by it.
Sweet and easy, a good cocktail whiskey

I have a bottle on hand at all times for when my parents visit. I have actually never tried it neat so I figured why not.   I really could not pull many notes other than honey and light maple. Finish is short. It is very smooth and easy to drink. I have poured this into my infinity bottle whenever I need to rest the flavor profile and it does that well. Other than that, only the parents ever drink it. I certainly will not be joining them! Cheers all.
I've had so many crowns I actually don't think I've had regular crown till tonight.  not bad... sippable... easy on the nose.  I got 6.5 more shots so this review will be longer soon...
OK neat but much better as a mixer. I give it a 2.5
Seemed to get some coconut in there
very smooth, but not much to it
There’s something off-putting about Crown Royal’s taste, almost like it seems unfocused. It’s just kind of bland. Couple that with a too-oily mouthfeel and I can’t see the draw of Crown.
This makes me feel like I am Jim Lahey from Trailer Park Boys falling over trying to be a cop.

While I most whisk(e)y I enjoy I take neat, Crown Royal is one whisky that I very much enjoy in cocktails, but don’t enjoy straight. Has a fairy sweetness to it, smooth and balanced in the sense that no specific flavor really stands out at all
Best so far. Smooth, caramel, and good aroma

Smell notes: strong notes of vanilla with hints of maple. Subtle, but pleasant sent overall.

Taste notes: very soft mouth feel with a light burn that increases slowly after swallowing. Watery consistency. Tastes of vanilla and maple. Barely any hints of alcohol, but does pick up in strength after swallowing.

Overall, surprised by how smooth this is and how the sweetness doesn’t overpower the taste.
Good Canadian Whisky just a little bit better but very similar then Canadian club in my opinion

There isn’t much on the nose which I think is unfortunate because typically it enhances the tasting experience. The body is very thin, but it is smooth. I picked up maple and vanilla sweetness but it just wasn’t that notable, not much of a finish as it fades quickly. Others have stated it is a good mixer and they are probably right, drinking it neat is rather blasé.
Spicyness, smooth, vanilla, fades away quickly.
Maybe because I had this after a few other drinks, just tasted like burny water to me. Maybe a fruity nose.
Smooth, but not tasting much flavor
Light and sweet. Smooth and easy to drink, and makes for a good mixer. However, if you’re looking for some complexity in terms of flavor, you’ll probably have to look elsewhere.
I don’t understand why this is popular

Noticeable presence of oil content that leaves a cinnamon spice aftertaste that stays on the tongue, extremely smooth throughout with a warming effect instead of a mouth burn and a sweet lingering note as a goodbye.

With a straw of mountain spring water it loses all that sweetness from before and becomes an allspice concoction that is just short of Maker's Mark on the scale, still maintains all the smoothness from before.

Mixed with some Pepsi in a highball (felt appropriate) it becomes very mellow but still has enough of a presence to not be forgotten, changes the Pepsi to be more allspice in nature just like with the mountain spring water, which is surprising as Pepsi is considered the sweetest of colas by many.
Strong aroma, sweet, syrup like taste of maple and vanilla
For me, not sure why this one is so well known. Did not enjoy straight and even prefer other mixers over this one.

Robust oak rye & vanilla nose, hints of smokiness & blend, mostly smooth, but hints of roughness,  spicy rye blended, hints of vanilla & oak, w/ cinnamon, & a smooth vanilla/oak cinnamon finish.
Tasted neat in a rocks glass.
Easy drinking and sweet dram. Nice for every day.
lons, week 6 LOSS 6-12... Crown "first time, long time"

Tasted a mini while watching the sunset, camping in Utah

Nose: an assault of sweetness - brown sugar and pure vanilla

Taste: tastes very young... maple, brown sugar, rye spice

Finish: short rye note on the end
Another classic go to. Hits the spot.  Cheap.  Plus, you get an awesome souvenir bag.  Not bad.
Maple, sugar, sweet and a short finish.   Good beginner's dram.
For the price, this is nice
Good ol' original Crown Royal. Solid "go to" whiskey for any occasion.

The nose has spicy oak, grape juice, peaches, and nuts. The smell is unique and you know you have a glass a Crown Royal in your hand as soon as you smell it. More spicy oak and grape juice on the palate, but behind a rich layer of vanilla. The finish is long with almonds and a few bitter notes at the end.

This whiskey is not something I would seek out to drink straight. For best results, mix with cranberry juice.
Smooth and sweet. A little warmth. Easy drinking, but maybe a bit forgettable
Slightly floral and ethereal, not overwhelmingly sweet, but approachable, universal and comforting in truly royal manner.
Wonderfuly smooth taste of vanilla with a spritz of maple. A hint of autumn flavor towards the end.

Smells like cream soda.
Sweet, with vanilla, sugar, and barrel tannins. It’s simple and clean.
Only have it a 3 because of the smoothness. Other than that, not much too it other than a very pronounced nutty flavor.
Slightly sweet, strong alcohol taste, somewhat rye spiced
Awesome whiskey, easy drinking. maple front but lacking a backend.

This year for the holidays I’m going to try a brand new whiskey every day in December. #lifegoals

Dec. 4:

Nose is minimal, but I get mild caramel.

Body is yeasty. Decent burn.

Finish has brine and black pepper.

Very basic whisky, but it’s fine. I’m actually quite impressed with this distiller in general based on some of their other offerings. Makes me feel like a bit of a tool, but I’m okay with Crown.

I don’t know if I actually have 27 more new whiskeys lined up, so if you’re reading this and there’s something readily available out there you’d like me to enjoy/suffer through this holiday season, leave it in the comments.
A little rough, even over ice.

Pretty good. Over time I’m finding I don’t care for it as much as others. It definitely tastes good but it’s simple and has no complexity. I have no problems drinking this if I have nothing else available.
Ok for mix and on rocks.
For a large commercial distillery it’s always pretty solid.
On the nose: hand sanitizer, perfume, and toffee. On the palette, it’s thin and sweet. Almost artificial sweetener sweet. With alcohol vapors and a stale maple syrup finish.

Coming back to this for the first time after starting my journey into understanding whiskey gave me a newfound appreciation for Crown. Rather than hate this as something cheap and universally available, I found this to be pleasant but simple.

I recall hating this much more when I was younger and would take shots of it at a bar.  However, tonight, I discovered a 2/3 empty bottle of Crown Royal in the back of my cooking cabinet, and curiosity got the better of me.

Coming from drinking cask strength bourbons on a regular basis, this had no burn whatsoever. Exceptionally smooth, with a juicy burst of white grape and pinot grigio. A discernible rye spice on the finish that surprised me.  Reminiscent of juicier, watered down, MGP Rye. 

I rarely drink 80 proof whiskey, but tonight's taste piqued my interest enough to have me pull out one of the few in my collection: standard, 4-year, Templeton Rye. Surprisingly, the crown had noticeable similarities, though obviously less spicy. 

I do wonder if regular crown tastes like this, or if sitting 2/3 full for years in the back of a cabinet helped It improve
Nothing special, bland but smooth atleast.

The wood and vanilla are immediately present. The flavor is slightly sweet and fruity and quite light. The whole presentation is fairly smooth and the flavor is pretty constant throughout. While it isn't super interesting, it is fairly tasty and unobjectionable.
A regular whisky. Nothing to celebrate about.
Vanilla, caramel, smooth as hell. That’s about it.
Sweet with Vanilla. Light, smooth, not terribly intresting.  Over priced.

Thought I'd revisit the whiskey mixers of my college years...
Crown and coke was a goto for me at parties. Now that I'm more experienced and my palate is a bit more nuanced, I thought I'd get a sample of CR Deluxe and see if I'm still fond of this whiskey

Overall, its smooth with vanilla, mild syrup, and some oak. A bit of citrus on the nose. The taste is a bit weak  with a woody finish that tastes a bit odd. Its so smooth to the point that flavor notes feel watered down. I'd relegate this to a mixer only. 

Not one I'd drink neat, but Crown and Coke still ain't half bad.
It's super smooth. Canadians really know how to make whiskey.

It's not rich, not too spicy, and not full-bodied. It's thin, on the sweet side, and lacks a big bite. Even the finish didn't have any kick. In other words, it's a good light sipper, a whisky that would go well with dessert, or after dinner. 
I'm not sure, but I think that was the plan from the beginning.
Chestnut brown, with standard alcohol legs. Nose- grain alcohol, with back-notes of rye and vanilla, with possible wood. Taste- corn, rye, vanilla, and oak. Medium body. Moderate-to-long finish. RJT
I would rank higher than expert 83. In fact when you switch from bourbon just as a change of pace —very good.

What can I say about crown? First bottle I ever legally purchased. It is readily available anywhere and very reasonably priced. Don't feel bad about any way you drink it. Neat, OTR, coke, sprite, just too many easy options. For 20$ and a good taste this one is hard to pass up.

Smooth and easy to drink. Warm, and sweet with vanilla, caramel and a little fruit. Being Canadian of course it won’t punch you in the palate but it doesn’t need to apologize either for being a nice drink.

Enjoying a tour of some of the brands I haven't touched in years for whatever reason.  The journey continues with Crown Royal, this taste coming from a 50ml nip that came complete with a little purple bag.  I love it!

Tasted neat from a glencairn.  The light amber pour has some sheeting and clingly legs after a swirl.  The nose is immediately off-putting with sharp ethanol and traces of acetone right up front.  I'm going to give it a good 10 minutes to sit before evaluating.

After a good, long wait elements of caramel and faint vanilla make an appearance.  Most of the chemical/alcohol notes faded away. What's left is the opposite of complex.

The first sip reveals a sweeter taste with a creamier mouthfeel than the nose advertised.  The upfront is actually pretty good, but the follow through is choppy and disconnected. There's a bitter finish that makes me not want another sip.  

And then comes a rather interesting lemony bit that makes me wonder if I'd taste it again on another sip. 

Wash, rinse, repeat.  Cloying introduction, sour departure.

I'll drink this on the rocks, or mixed, anyplace where this is the best choice I have.  It's not horrible for a fully mainstream, mass market name brand delivered in a plastic bottle.  That does't mean I want it in my cabinet. It is, at it's best. wholly average.

My scale of 1 to 5 places the peak of the bell curve at 2.5.  Most competent, but unremarkable, whiskies will be found between 2 and 3 on this scale. 

Hard pass on buying a bottle.

It has been a long time since I have had Crown Royal and just recently I broke down and bought a bottle. I have changed because when I was a young lad this was a strong drink but now it is a thin light liquor. For a Canadian whiskey, it is not bad and I do give them credit for a great marketing department it just does not have the flavor or strength of even the most basic Bourbons like Jim Beam white-label or Evan Williams 1783. For the price, if one bottle of CR I could get half a gallon of Evan Williams 1783.

Ok, im impressed. I've never expected to  get a nice experience from this whisky. Crown Royal deluxe blended scotch, Canadian most famous spirit, is well balanced, tasty, and elegant. On the nose is creamy with vanilla notes, a little floral or herbal. On the palate, it start very sweet, with caramel, honey and toffee notes, to change into a spicy but gentle sensation. the finish is medium, with a different, mint flavor. Never before have i experienced mint caramel on a whisky. Nice dram
Solid Canadian... If not the benchmark. Sweet maple and smooth body make it infinitely drinkable in a cocktail, shots, or neat.
I'd drink this if it was the only whiskey available...
Sweet rich flavor of maple, vanilla, and wood spice. Creamy, smooth, medium finish.
Like a watered down bourbon with syrup added
Hits you with fruity, apricot taste, mixed with smooth vanilla finish.
Not as good as I thought prior to having great quality
